column5: I‚Äôm recently got on 300mg wellbutrin and yesterday was the first time that I woke up and actually wanted to clean my room.
There are other options if you dont want to loose your sex drive. Agomelatine, Wellbutrin, Tianeptine, Trintellix etc.
It might be worth looking into buspirone or tianeptine then. Actually, just tell your doctor. Don‚Äôt settle with something that doesn‚Äôt make you feel normal.
Well I meant that there are other options for treating depression like vilazodone, vortioxetine, mirtazapine, bupropion etc.

Was celexa the first med you‚Äôve tried? I don‚Äôt understand why are SSRIs still prescribed as a first line medications when there‚Äôs better newer medications that don‚Äôt cause sexual problems ü§î
I enjoy dreams 10x more than my life now.
You can still vape, eat edibles or use tinctures.

What was your reason for wanting to go on SNRI over an SSRI? They seem to be mostly the same in terms of side effects (minus the weight gain). Also Effexor seems to be mainly an SRI, because it has 10 times higher affinity for SERT than it has for NERT. Was it because of weight gain?
Well 150mg only had mild effect on me, now I‚Äôm on 300mg and I hope it helps.

Yeah it‚Äôs so sad that there is nothing that would work so well without causing tolerance. I‚Äôm glad that I only got into kratom, I‚Äôve tried smoking heroin once (lol) and it was ofc too good to be true.

Not when right away when I started it but I started feeling more subconscious anxiety after maybe a week but it mostly went away after another 2 weeks but unfortunately other effects became almost unnoticeable too. I hope 300mg will have more of a lasting effect.
I‚Äôm on Wellbutrin rn and I actually feel less anxiety after I increased my dose to 300mg, but it‚Äôs also pretty early to judge I guess, because it‚Äôs only been 4 days since the increase.

Have you tried strattera or Wellbutrin? While they are mostly just NRIs, they last much longer without the typical stimulant side effects and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition is thought to increase levels of dopamine in certain parts of the brain like the prefrontal cortex.

I wish stimulants would be used as an adjunct here, but I guess doctors are not that open minded here or maybe they don‚Äôt consider prescribing controlled substances worth the potential problems with drug agencies or idk. Either way it‚Äôs sad because they wouldn‚Äôt think twice while prescribing antipsychotic that cause horrible permanent side effects.

I‚Äôm on Wellbutrin right and while I really hope it will help, if it doesn‚Äôt my options would be limited. I won‚Äôt try another emotionally blunting medication, so I guess the only ones left are agomelatine and tianeptine and then ECT or rTMS.
Thank you üôÇ

Yes, I think that a reuptake inhibitor could potentially be the least likely to cause any serious side effects. And if it would take a couple weeks to build up the effects like SSRIs, the abuse potential would be low.

Yes I know that it‚Äôs very expensive :(

Have you tried supplements that help with drug cravings like NAC? It seems to be effective at reducing cocaine intake and cravings, so it should theoretically work for ritalin as well, because they have a similar mechanism.
Maybe try strattera or wellbutrin? Antipsychotics are generally not addictive but ritalin won‚Äôt give you permanent uncomfortable movements.

I live in the EU but I‚Äôve read that its available in US too, but it might be banned in some states, but I don‚Äôt know any specific site unfortunately :( But I would advice you to try to find a trusted vendor, because some of them have shit quality and you would only be underwhelmed.

I take Wellbutrin, I just wonder why is there only one medication like this and tons of different serotonin reuptake inhibitors. Some people might not tolerate Wellbutrin but would benefit from a similar medication with a different side effect profile. Also Wellbutrin is basically just NRI, because of it‚Äôs metabolism. It still affects dopamine in certain parts of the brain by inhibiting NERT, but it‚Äôs nowhere near to what was thought before.

I was on 150mg Wellbutrin and it worked wonderfully until the effects settled and then it was underwhelming, my doctor recently upped the dose to 300mg (which is maximum here) and while I hope its going to help, if it doesnt there wont be a lot of options as I refuse to take another ssri or snri, maois are not available in my country and I wouldnt touch antipsychotics.

SSRI drugs work for some people but honestly their effectiveness isn‚Äôt optimal, they just don‚Äôt work at all for a significant amount of people and they cause some degree of emotional in up to 70% of people taking it. Which might be a welcomed effect for some people, but for people that already have more of a apathetic kind of depression it‚Äôs not really helpful.

Amphetamines are not even available in my country, idk why. And most psychiatrists here seem to be pretty conservative when it comes to prescribing medications off-label. I can‚Äôt imagine being prescribed methylphenidate for depression here unfortunately :(

I‚Äôve tried it and it felt exactly the same as an ssri, just less intense and gave me digestive issues that lasted for a month after I stopped taking it. It might be useful for some people that can tolerate it though as it might directly help with the cognitive impairment caused by depression.
Yeah it‚Äôs a shame that opiates cause rapid tolerance haha. I self medicated with kratom, but it wasnt really sustainable.

That‚Äôs an oversimplification IMO. Meth is obviously very potent and long lasting and it doesn‚Äôt just inhibit the reuptake of dopamine, it also releases it in huge amounts. Same goes for amphetamine but one of the likely reasons why meth is more addictice is that it actually realeases more serotonin that amphetamine as well.  Methylphenidate only inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine and it‚Äôs significantly less addictive than amphetamines.

Serotonin reuptake inhibitors also cause rapid tolerance the same way, but their effect is most likely somewhere else ‚Äúbehind‚Äù the reuptake inhibition, they might be changing gene expression or something else, nobody really knows. It might possibly be the same for the inhibition of dopamine reuptake. The desired effect wouldn‚Äôt come from the initial increase of dopamine but from what comes after it.

I haven‚Äôt personally experienced anything like akathisia before the treatment with antidepressants, so Im sure it was caused by them. Escitalopram made me feel full body restlessness and Vortioxetine was similar but a little better. Mirtazapine gave me some weird feeling like a restless leg syndrome but in my left arm lol, it paradoxically made me unable to fall asleep especially when I started taking it, but even when it didnt it was driving me crazy. Now I‚Äôm on Wellbutrin and I don‚Äôt experience anything like that anymore.

True, I guess it‚Äôs very individual, the problem though seems to be that there is a lot of options for one ‚Äútype‚Äù of depression and not enough for others. Most of the medications seem to do just about the same thing, with different side effect profiles. I guess that SSRIs and similar meds might indirectly increase positive emotions in cases when negative ones ‚Äúblock‚Äù them. But multiple studies have shown that up to 70% of people experience emotional blunting and serotonergic antidepressants are much more likely to cause it than antidepressants with different mechanisms like bupropion or agomelatine.

If the biochemistry in depression is so individual, then why are most of the pharmacological treatment options so one-dimensional? Why is there only one NDRI approved as an antidepressant (bupropion) but a ton of different SSRIs and similar. 

To say that dopamine is solely responsible for positive affect is of course very simplified, but it really seems to play an important role when it comes to reward processing which can for a lot of people be the reason behind anhedonia, especially when it‚Äôs the main symptom or when it‚Äôs a residual symptom after treatment with serotonergic antidepressants.

Well it doesn‚Äôt have to be stronger than wellbutrin, it could possibly be similar with different side effect profile. Just like there is a ton of different ssris. Also wellbutrin is mostly just a NRI because of its metabolism. So the potential medication could be more of a balanced NDRI. It doesn‚Äôt have to be overly stimulating. Stimulation or drive doesn‚Äôt really equal to the ability to experience joy.

Im on wellbutrin right now and it‚Äôs the first med that actually works a little after trying 4 other antidepressants that all just made me a zombie. Im not yet sure if it only affects my drive or if it also increases the joy I get from things, because 150mg was very mild and after 4 weeks almost insignificant, now I‚Äôm on 300mg since three days ago and I‚Äôm really curious if it‚Äôs going to help.

I don‚Äôt think that anhedonia is a part of being an adult, a lot of people are very passionate about their hobbies or work, while for me everything is the just meh and dull. I‚Äôm really not willing to just live like this for the sake of living.

Yes currently there is not a lot of options, but that seems more like a reason to look for new medications that wouldn‚Äôt have the drawbacks of existing ones, while all the recently introduced antidepressant have essentially the same effect of numbing emotions, only with different side effects. Wouldn‚Äôt there be a higher possibility of success when trying a medication with a different effect than as opposed to trying a medication with virtually the same intended effect? Particularly in patients with no response to first-line agents.

It seems to me that the reason why the effectiveness of treatment with current antidepressant isn‚Äôt optimal is that most of the medications are too focused on only one of the core symptoms of depression - depressed mood, but there is a lack of options for treating anhedonia.

What also seems upsetting to me is that most doctors would rather put their patient on antipsychotics and possibly cause them permanent movement side effects than trying medications with a small abuse potential (that could be minimized by carefully monitoring them). I would personally take addiction over a movement disorder without a second thought, movement disorders are hell on earth. Prescribing antipsychotics for people without psychosis, mania or severe treatment resistant depression is immoral IMHO.

Actually ketamine seems to be promising in how fast it acts, but it has it‚Äôs own drawbacks.

Or ECT.

Actually I would say would say that treating anhedonia with dopaminergic drugs would decrease the likehood of developing addiction, like it does in people with ADHD. And I that if such potential medication would take weeks to have an effect like other antidepressants, it would further decrease the abuse potential.

It‚Äôs crazy and upsetting how doctors would rather have you on a antipsychotic with terrible possibly permanent side effects, than having you try other stuff like stimulants just because of abuse potential. 

I believe that there alternatives to SSRI that don‚Äôt inhibit dopamine like Mirtazapine, but I think that the dopamine inhibition is only a part of this problem, I think that the numbing is directly caused by it‚Äôs effect on serotonin. Agomelatine seems like an interesting option, it helps with anxiety, but I‚Äôm not sure about OCD.

I had the same experience with SSRIs in regards to reward seeking behavior like binge eating and excessive alcohol use. They also made my ability to focus on things even worse.

It has a potential to cause permanent movement disorders like tardive dyskinesia and dystonia. I‚Äôm not really willing to risk that. I already experience mild tremor and fasciculations and I had a couple months long period of intense muscle twitching/involuntary movements after an infection and let me tell you it was absolutely horrible. I wouldn‚Äôt want to ever risk getting something similar but permanent. Maybe as a last resort after trying every other type of meds and ECT.

The reason why I‚Äôm asking the question in my post is that there could possibly be medications that would achieve a similar effect without the risk of permanent side effects (through a different mechanism like reuptake inhibition).

Haha yeah I‚Äôm sure my doctor would be down to do some lines with me. Seriously though, there are some similarities between cocaine and the antidepressant bupropion and ADHD meds like methylphenidate, but cocaine also inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and is pretty cardiotoxic.

Hmm that one looks really interesting. It even has higher affinity for dopamine reuptake than serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake. But it‚Äôs prodrug to venlafaxine, so I wonder how much of it actually gets metabolized into venlafaxine.

I‚Äôm not sure but it‚Äôs the main metabolite of venlafaxine so chances are that it‚Äôs very similar. One of it‚Äôs uses is treating anxiety disorders. It‚Äôs very similar to SSRIs actually, it‚Äôs inhibition of norepinephrine is 10x weaker than the inhibition of serotonin. One potential difference is that it doesn‚Äôt seem to cause weight gain and it might be a little more stimulating.

That‚Äôs a no for me. Maybe as a last resort after trying things like ECT. I‚Äôve already experienced a temporary movement disorder after an infection and let me tell you it‚Äôs the worst feeling ever. It‚Äôs hard to imagine it if you never experienced it. I don‚Äôt want to risk getting a permanent dyskinesia or dystonia from an antipsychotic.

Not to mention other horrible side effects like cognitive impairment (already have that from depression), akathisia (had that even on escitalopram) etc. and potential negative effects on brain and metabolism. I don‚Äôt understand why so many doctors seem to be so benevolent when prescribing antipsychotics for things other than psychosis or mania. Seems really unethical to me.

I understand that for some people it might be the only thing that works, but I believe it should truly be reserved as a last resort.  That also leads me to my original question, why aren‚Äôt there antidepressants that affect dopamine in other safer ways than antipsychotics - for example reuptake inhibitors?

I‚Äôm on Wellbutrin actually. It‚Äôs much more of an NRI than DRI because of it‚Äôs metabolism. But to be fair norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake mechanism seems to be interconnected in some parts of the brain. 150mg made me feel much better at first, then after 1-2 weeks it seemed to only increase drive and didn‚Äôt really help with enjoying things that much and then after another 2 weeks I didn‚Äôt feel any significant benefit from taking it anymore, so my doctor upped the dose to 300mg 2 days ago. I hope it‚Äôs going to work better in the long-term at this dose.

Yes but it‚Äôs primarily an SRI, even it‚Äôs NRI action is much weaker compared to it. It still has all the effects of an SRI with a small bonus at best. It still works mainly by numbing emotions and it causes sexual dysfunction as well. I wish there were more options for people that want the increase in motivation and positive emotions without emotional numbing.

Interesting, I‚Äôll look into L-Tyrosine. I‚Äôm trying NAC now with bupropion as it seems to be potentially beneficial for anhedonia and I hope to use it to reduce my need to use alcohol for social interaction. Interestingly the Glutamatergic system seems to have a role in anhedonia as well.

Yes but it‚Äôs affinity for SERT is so much higher than for DAT to the point that it‚Äôs debatable if it‚Äôs DRI are clinically significant. It still causes emotional blunting and sexual dysfunction just like other SSRIs. IMO it‚Äôs not really useful for people that just want a boost in positive emotions and motivation without numbing.
Those aren‚Äôt even available in my country anymore, but they are still prohibited from importing. What a joke.
Yes it‚Äôs more of an NRI but I red that the metabolism of norepinephrine and dopamine is related, especially in prefrontal cortex.
I agree 100% but doctors don‚Äôt care. All they ever offered me were antidepressants that just made me numb and bored to death.

Thank you for your answer.

I don‚Äôt want to take SSRIs or SNRIs as I already have reduced emotions and their intended effect seems to be reducing emotions (and by that reducing anxiety). Escitalopram killed all my emotions and only reduced my anxiety by 50% and that is not worth for me at all. I was on only 10mg and I guess that lowering the dosage would make the effect on anxiety insignificant. Trazodone, Vortioxetine and Mirtazapine basically did the same but to a lesser extent. 

Benzos help dramatically but they are really not a solution for me because I experience constant subconscious anxiety that doesn‚Äôt change all that much in different situations.

Beta-blockers seem interesting, I wonder if they have any influence on cognition, especially memory and focus, as I already have aproblem with those because of depression. I‚Äôm also afraid that they would interact with or counteract the effect of Wellbutrin (which is so far the only antidepressant that has at least a small positive effect on my depression) or cause depression as a side-effect. 

I probably wouldn‚Äôt be able to handle the side effects of TCAs, especially the cognitive ones that come from their anticholinergic properties.

I think that the problem with me is that my baseline state is pretty paradoxical, because I experience severe anhedonia, apathy and cognitive impairment from depression and constant subconscious anxiety that makes me feel like shit physically (shaking hands, twitches, involuntary muscle movements and tense muscles). It feels like when a medication helps with one, it worsens the other and vice versa :(

I thought that the link between anticholinergic  drugs and dementia only applies to drugs that are antagonists of muscarinic acetylcholine receptors and bupropion only antagonizes nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. But I might be wrong. Does the TCA influence your cognition in any way? I already experience severe significant cognitive impairment from depression :( I can‚Äôt focus at all.

Why is it considered a separate syndrome by medical experts then? It‚Äôs just a part of a spectrum with other nerve hyperexcitability disorders, like cramp fasciculation syndrome and Isaacs syndrome. And in my personal experience it doesn‚Äôt correlate with anxiety at all, it‚Äôs basically the same all the time. Also, antidepressant medication didn‚Äôt help with it while it made me unable to feel any emotion. Also it appeared out of nowhere one day when I had mycoplasma lung infection and it was very severe for 3 months andthe gradually got better and now reached a plateau. Also I was never worried about  it being ALS or anything like that.

No it‚Äôs not. It‚Äôs normal to twitch once in a while but it‚Äôs definately not normal to twitch all the time, experience cramps and involuntary muscle jerks etc. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs a separate syndrome and not a just a symptom of anxiety disorders. For me personally I tried multiple antidepressants and some of them made me feel almost no emotions at all and the BFS was still the same ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Yeah but for some people the twitching is so prominent that it makes their life misserable. Especially when other symptoms show up, like myoclonus and cramping. And then doctors basically tell them to fuck off because iT‚Äôs jUst BeNiGn blah blah blah :(

No therapy doesn‚Äôt help at all unfortunately. I don‚Äôt see the point in talking about how I feel, I don‚Äôt understand how is it going to help me and tbh I mostly just feel nothing. 22 sessions and I don‚Äôt see any benefit. I can‚Äôt do meditation currently because i can‚Äôt focus on anything at all for more than couple seconds, tbh I feel so empty that it‚Äôs not bearable anymore. I‚Äôm trying to find any help possible for a year already but I only feel worse and that is very demotivating. I have another appointment with my psychiatrist today, I hope it‚Äôs going to help, but I honestly don‚Äôt believe it will.
Causemula

Do you feel ‚Äúnormal‚Äù on SSRI? For me it helped with anxiety but killed every other feeling I had. So did Trazodone, Mirtazapine and Vortioxetine. Noe I‚Äôm on 150mg Wellbutrin and it doesn‚Äôt do much, I just snap at people randomly and I‚Äôm completely asocial because of it :(

Ive macrodosed and reached total ego death.
Ive done shrooms multiple times and they didn‚Äôt hrlp with anxiety. It‚Äôs individual. I agree that there are better meds than ssris.

I didn‚Äôt mean to say that there is interaction, I just read from a few articles and studies that there is a high correlation between concurrent alcohol use and moclobemide treatment failure. Im no expert tho, I just read it :)
This is just not true, they won‚Äôt all poop out, at least not for majority of people. Stop scaring people and discouraging them from getting help. Not everything can be fixed by therapy.
Thug looked pretty geeked up during the no jumper interview, like he took a addy.
Yeah, I think my new doctor is better than those I had before, so he might be willing to do so. Thank you for the suggestion :)
I mean unfortunately because it means less options. Moclobemide is interesting but I‚Äôve heard that it doesn‚Äôt work if you drink alcohol and I‚Äôm not really willing to give that up :(
It‚Äôs not available in my country :( only metoprolol, I guess that‚Äôs similar ?
I wish propranolol was a available in my country, but it‚Äôs not :( I really don‚Äôt understand why. But there is metoprolol and I guess that one might be kinda similar.

No, but close - Czech Republic.
I don‚Äôt think that dopamine feast would work as anhedonia itself should cause dopamine receptor upregulation.
I‚Äôm really scared of the side effects of TCAs, like shaking (I already shake 24/7) and higher risk of developing dementia :(

But I don‚Äôt even know what is my anxiety trigger, I‚Äôm in fight or flight mode 24/7. I‚Äôm always shaking, having uncontrollable body jerks and twitches and clenching my muscles, no matter where I am or what Im doing. I don‚Äôt even worry about anything excessively, I‚Äôm actually quite apathetic. I feel like my anxiety is 95% physical.

After trying Escitalopram I don‚Äôt want to try any SSRIs ever again, it stole four months of my life and it took another two months to fully recover from it. I‚Äôm scared of trying TCAs because I already experience tremor and because they higher the chance of getting dementia later in life. Unfortunately the only maoi available in my country is Moclobemide :(
I let him help me 5 times already and it always just made things worse. And it was 2 psychatrists in fact, I had to change.
Does it affect your cognition (memory, concentration)? Do you still feel normal emotions?

Escitalopram, trazodone, vortioxetine, mirtazapine and now wellbutrin. All of the medications except wellbutrin had the same effect of making me feel anhedonic and numb + restless. Wellbutrin on the other hand only helps with depression (a little).

Yes, dead is worse for other people, but feeling no emotions is worse for me. Do I really have to choose between feeling physically anxious all the time and feeling no emotions at all? Also lowering dosage doesn‚Äôt help, it stops doing anything.

Yes but I think that emotional numbness is the intended effect of serotonergic meds and while some people might enjoy that effect, for me it‚Äôs horrible. I don‚Äôt want to try another med that affects serotonin receptors, because I can already tell the outcome, but I know it‚Äôs probably what the doctor isb going to prescribe since this side effect is not taken seriously by most doctors. For me being so numb is worse than being dead.
Effexor is mainly a serotonergic med, it only has weak norepinephrine reuptake inhibition.
Very funny, you‚Äôre such a funny guy haha. I hope you feel great about yourself, fucking dickhead.

It‚Äôs safe in any amount, it‚Äôs just not recommended...

Thank you for your reply. I really don‚Äôt mean to deter anyone from trying medication, I believe it might be solution for some people if it fits their brain chemistry well. My problem is not that I have too many negative emotions, it‚Äôs that I lack positive emotions, so there it feels like there is no reward for anything I put effort in. Most antidepressants numb emotions, so while they might work for emotional people, for me they make me loose the little interest I have left in anything. Now I‚Äôm on wellbutrin and while it‚Äôs different from other meda and actually somehow helps, I just can‚Äôt shake the feeling that this is nothing like how I felt before all these issues. Also therapy doesn‚Äôt work for me, because it‚Äôs impossible to work with emotions when I hardly feel any.
Why are you being downvoted for sharing personal experience.
Just try something else, imo there are better drugs for anxiety than SSRIs/SNRIs these days.

Yes, I‚Äôm on it for a little more than 2 weeks now, but so far I only have mild effects, but I‚Äôm still on a low dose (150mg). It‚Äôs definitely better than all the meds I‚Äôve tried, I feel like it actually helps the problem instead of hiding it. It makes me a little more physically anxious, but that‚Äôs tolerable.
I think it‚Äôs mostly placebo, the plasma levels of it shouldn‚Äôt change much after one day of not taking it, unless it has very short half-life.

I wish there would be a med for me that would work for anxiety without dulling all other emotions. Most of antidepressants seem to me like using a cannon to kill a fly. I really hope that there will more specific selective meds in the near future. Wellbutrin is the only one so far that seems to work in the opposite direction, but it doesnt work that well for anxiety.

If I‚Äôm not mistaken Efferox is a very weak norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitor compared to it‚Äôs serotonin reuptake inhibition. Wellbutrin is for sure more similar to standart ADHD meds.
I think that it‚Äôs the Mirtazapine that does that. It can even cause hallucinations if you take couple times more than the maximum dose.
Wow so lamotrigine helps your cognition? I‚Äôm interested in it as it might treat some of my comorbid problems, but I was afraid of the cognitive side effects.

Don‚Äôt worry I can think critically.

For me it would be a very positive effect because of the horrendous weight gain I experienced on Mirtazapine , unfortunately it‚Äôs my 7th day on Welbutrin and I only feel slight appetite suppression, but I hope it will still make some difference in the long term.
Also lexapro can make you grind your teeth. Even when you‚Äôre asleep.

Yes I‚Äôm only 7 days on it but it‚Äôs definately starting to work. Trazodone, Escitalopram and Mirtazapine all just masked the problem and made me a mindless numb zombie. I wish Wellbutrin was prescribed more as first line.

You‚Äôre so lucky that serotonergic drugs work so well for you. For me they made everything feel really dull, no negative but also no positive emotions. Just nothingness. I recently started Wellbutrin XL and it‚Äôs the first drug that seems to aftually amplify my emotions, which is what I need, because you can only work with your emotions, when you actually feel them.
This combination doesn‚Äôt cause serotonin syndrome. Wellbutrin doesn‚Äôt affect serotonin.

I read that it‚Äôs statistically not really worth it to try third ssri, especially since citalopram and lexapro are almost the same drug. I‚Äôd rather try some atypical antidepressants now as their side effects are very different. For example Mirtazapine should have less side effects.

I think he‚Äôs right, clonazepam loses it effectivness over time and makes you just dependent on it. The withdrawal symptoms can last months and can even kill you. It makes you‚Äôre cognitive functions much worse and it highers the risk of developing dementia. There is a lot of better options that you can try and you‚Äôll thank yourself later.
Psychoactive doesn‚Äôt equal neurotoxic. Most psychoactive substances are not neurotoxic in therapeutic dosages.

For me it caused a little very slow weight gain, it was easy to control for sure. I was then prescribed Mirtazapine which caused rapid weight gain, but for me weight gain was undesirable, so I want to switch to Wellbutrin soon in hopew that it will help me loose weight.
At least its the first time that being an introvert in this society feels like an advantage rather than something undesirable and frown upon.

I‚Äôm also going to ask my psychiatrist about one of these because all the meds I‚Äôve tried made me feel very emotionally flat and unmotivated. Agomelatine particularly interest me as it has very different properties compared to conventional antidepressants like ssris
SSRIs can actually decrease dopamine levels in some parts of the brain. That might be the reason why so many people feel less motivation while on them.
